did.unittitle: Women in Animation oral histories and records

physdesc.extent: (10 unprocessed optical discs, 6 unprocessed floppy disks, 1 unprocessed hard drive)

did.abstract: Women in Animation (now WIA) was created in 1993 to support the small number of women in the field of animation through community building and professional networking opportunities. The collection consists of oral history transcripts from interviews conducted by the organization, Women in Animation, and its business records.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS DIGITAL AND AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: This collection contains both processed and unprocessed digital and audiovisual materials. For information about the access status of the material that you are looking for, refer to the Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note at the series and file levels. All requests to access processed digital and audiovisual materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Reproduction and Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Women in Animation, Inc., 1999.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Women in Animation oral histories and records (PASC 222). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Final processing by Preksha Ambrish in consultation with Kelly Besser, 2024.
Digital materials were received on 10 optical discs. All digital file naming, organization, and arrangement created by Women in Animation was retained.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's Library Collections and Archives.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Women in Animation (now WIA) was created in 1993 to support the small number of women in the field of animation through community building and professional networking opportunities. Since then, WIA has evolved into the advocacy group supporting female- identifying and non-binary people in animation, visual effects, and gaming, and includes over 11,000 members worldwide.
Description from Women in Animation website, accessed July 2024.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of oral history transcripts from interviews conducted by the organization, Women in Animation, and its business records. Contains interviews with women pioneers from the animation industry, including Frances Arriola, Susan Ashley, Barbara Baldwin, Betty Brooks, Martha Buckley, Xenia De Mattia, Becky Fallberg, Mary Jane Frost, Grace Godino, Wilma Guenot, Julie Harvey, Anneline Liu, Joan Orbison, Sylvia Roemer, Martha Sigall, Gini Swift and Auril Thompson. The interviews are varied in terms of positions held and talents expressed while in the animation industry.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This collection has been arranged in the following series:
Series 1: Oral histories
Series 2: Records

odd.head: General
odd.p: These 17 cassettes have been digitized and can be found \avpres\LSC\PASC\WomenInAnimation_pasc_222

phystech.p: CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Audiovisual materials are available for access. All requests to access digital materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
